title: Hungry leopard dives into a muddy puddle to snatch up a floundering fish in its jaws
text:
This is the moment a leopard caught an enormous fish trapped in a puddle that was once a much bigger waterhole.

The fascinating clip shows the hungry predator dip its paws in the muddy water in South Africa's Kruger National Park before biting down on a floundering barbel and hauling it out.

Tayla McCurdy and a group of friends witnessed the spectacular catch on Thursday afternoon after driving along the Mphongolo Loop and spotting the male leopard lingering near the pool filled with jumping fish.

The clip shows the hungry predator dip its paws in the muddy water in South Africa's Kruger National Park

She told Latest Sightings the puddle seemed to be all that remained of a 'thriving waterhole' thanks to a hot summer with very little rain.

Ms McCurdy said: 'We watched as the barbel splashed and moved about in the pool, in the little water there was to swim in.

'The leopard was nervous and disappeared below the embankment where we could no longer see him but we waited, knowing that this is an easy meal but not knowing if the leopard would go for it.

'After about 10 minutes the leopard eventually reappeared and stalked closer to the water. The writhing barbel were too much of a temptation and so the leopard slowly approached the puddle – planning the hunt.

Ms McCurdy said: 'We watched as the barbel splashed and moved about in the pool, in the little water there was to swim in'

'He hesitated for a while and then made his move. At first, it seemed like the barbel were slipping from his grasp as they viciously splashed – causing the leopard to dip his head almost completely into the muddy water.

'He finally grabbed a hold of his prize, then moved back below us out of sight.'

Leopards are carnivores who prey on any animal that comes across their path, including gazelles, amphibians, fish, antelopes, cheetah cubs, baboons, rodents, monkeys, snakes, large birds, warthogs and porcupines.

The morning after the incident the group went for another drive in the direction of the waterhole and found the same leopard - identified by the head-to-tail coat of mud - sitting on an embankment in the distance.

He walked over to where an 'enormous' barbel was lying in the sand.

Ms McCurdy said the puddle seemed like it used to be a 'thriving waterhole' that dried up to just a puddle due to the heat and very little rain over the summer

The group were not sure if this had been the same one that was caught the day before, or if this one was a fresh catch for the day.

The leopard picked up the barbel and took it to the shade of a Nyala Berry Tree where it could finally feast on its meal.

Ms McCurdy said said it was a 'very exciting' sighting, and 'definitely not something you see every day'.
description: The hungry predator dips its paws in the muddy water in South Africa's Kruger National Park before biting down on a floundering barbel and hauling it away.
